c52afe0668c462a5935a708cb396d234eeb018d4.commitMessage:
Add --fail-if-no-tests command line option to ConsoleLauncher (#1399)

Prior to this commit, if the ConsoleLauncher found no tests it would
exit with a success status. This could happen by user mistake -- for
example, due to improper use of a selector. In such situations, a user
would not be informed of the misconfiguration.

This commit introduces a new `--fail-if-not-tests` command-line option
for the ConsoleLauncher. This flag can be set to `true` to make the
launcher fail when no tests are found, helping users catch such
misconfigurations.

Closes: #1298

b3cec572c6334095f84ec009d5488370119e62c9.commitMessage:
Emit helpful message when a configuration key is not unique

Prior to this commit a bug [1] in Java 8's stream toMap() collector did
report the value instead of the duplicated key in the exception message.
Now, a custom list-to-map helper always emits a helpful error message.

[1] https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8040892

Closes #1308

3e042ee4923b029711682d81cec89e33d48cf842.commitMessage:
Add "--scan-module-path" to the command line options

Internally it is treated as if "--select-module ALL-MODULES" was given.
In the future "--scan-module-path" might support custom path entries
that are routed to the 'ModuleFinder.of(...)' factory method allowing
custom module-paths to be specified at runtime.

a64e354fa285ecd9297521ca327d9fbed34c21c9.commitMessage:
Introduce ASCII-based tree printing TestExecutionListeners

This commit introduces `TreePrintingListener` and
`VerboseTreePrintingListener` which render ASCII-based tree layouts for
the executed test plan. If the default character set encoding (e.g.,
for the terminal or build environment) is UTF-8, then extended ASCII
characters are used to display the test execution tree; otherwise,
standard 7-bit ASCII characters are used to display the test tree.

A new enum named `Details` has been introduced in the
`org.junit.platform.console.options` package in order to allow the user
to choose between various display modes:

 - NONE: No test plan execution details are printed.
 - FLAT: Test plan execution details are rendered in a flat,
   line-per-line mode.
 - TREE: Test plan execution details are rendered as a simple tree.
 - VERBOSE: Combines tree and flat mode.

Consequently, the original `ColoredPrintingTestListener` has been
renamed to `FlatPrintingListener`.

In addition, the `--hide-details` command line option is now deprecated
in favor of `--details none`.

Issues: #369, #546

---
I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.

e568a3563c417829a20eec988daa98797c8391b3.commitMessage:
Always use status code on exit. (#338)

I consider it helpful to always return a status code that is not 0 in
case of a failure. This makes it easy for scripts to decide whether all
tests succeeded. In addition I cannot imagine any use case that relies
on returning 0 in case of a failure.

The old implementation returned the number of failing tests as status
code if the flag `enable-exit-code` has been set. But this is only
possible for a small number (< 256) of failing tests. The problem was
that n*256 failing tests have been reported as 0 failing tests and
therefore could not be distinguished from a successful run by status
code.

The parser in `AvailableOptions` still accepts the `enable-exit-code`
flag because the project is build with an older version of the Gradle
plugin from https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots The
parser does not to have accept the flag anymore once a new version of
the Gradle plugin is pushed to the snapshot repository.
